sentences.original: ayah pêyak âhcî ê-ki-sôniyâwokimâwit ôtah nêhiyânâhk, êkwah pêyak âpihtawikosisân pôl kapinêt, êyakôw pîhtokêwak minihkwêwikamikohk.
sentences.text: aya pêyak âhcî ê-kî-sôniyâwokimâwit ôta nêhiyânâhk êkwa pêyak âpihtawikosisân pôl kapinêt êwako pîhtokêwak minihkwêwikamikohk
sentences.english: A certain man named Archie, who was Indian Agent here in the Cree country, and a halfbreed, Paul Caplette, entered a tavern.

sentences.original: êkosi, mitoni cî kinisitohtên nêhiyawêwin ? itêw awa kaplêt, sôniyâw-okimâw êh-itât.
sentences.text: êkosi itêw awa kaplêt sôniyâw-okimâw ê-itât
sentences.english: Then, “Do you understand the Cree language very well this Caplette asked him, asked the Indian Agent.
“Why, I speak Cree very well!” the other answered him.

sentences.original: hâ, kîspin kinêhiyawân, kîspin mitoni kwayask kinisitohtên nêhiyawêwin, wanowêhkâtânih, kika-minahâwak ôtah tahtoh k-âyâcik pîhcâyihk âpihtawokosisânak.
sentences.english: “Well then, if you speak Cree, if you understand the Cree language very well, then, if I speak so that you cannot understand me, you will treat to drinks as many halfbreeds as are in here.

sentences.original: mâka kîspin êkâ wanowêhkâtânih, niya nika-minahiwân.
sentences.english: But if I do not put you at a loss by my speech, then I shall stand the drinks.
What is this: 'With nary a fail,' what is this?”

sentences.original: êkosi, â, kontah êh-osîhtâyin, êh-itêyihtaman! itik awa kisêyiniw kaplêt.
sentences.english: Then, “Oh, you are just making it up, because you think you speak Cree so well!” said the other to old man Caplette.

sentences.original: â, êkosi minahiwê! itêw awa kaplêt.
sentences.english: “Ho, so now stand the drinks!” Caplette answered him.

sentences.original: êkosi awa sôniyâw-okimâw isiwêpinêw napakihtakohk nyânanwâpisk.
sentences.text: êkosi awa sôniyâw-okimâw isiwêpinêw napakihtakohk niyânanwâpisk
sentences.english: Thereupon the Indian Agent threw five dollars on the bar.

sentences.original: nânitaw nyânanosâp êkotah pîhcâyihk êh-ayâyit, êkonih kahkiyaw êh-minahât, nayêstaw nkotwâsik sôniyâs âyiwâkipayiw anihi nyânanwâpisk.
sentences.text: nânitaw niyânanosâp êkota pîhcâyihk ê-ayâyit êkoni kahkiyaw ê-minahât nayêstaw nikotwâsik sôniyâs ayiwâkipayiw anihi niyânanwâpisk
sentences.english: As there were about fifteen men in the place, when he had treated them all, only six bits were left of that five dollars.
“Well, you will never put me at a loss again:
Because I thought 'I too speak Cree,' is why I lost my money for nothing.”
“Because you talk a foreigner's Cree, the Cree language is poor and of small extent.

sentences.original: pêyak kêkway mihcêtwayak isiyîhkâtêw, mitoni tâ-nisitohtamihk nêhiyawêwin.
sentences.english: But each thing has many names, when the Cree language is well understood.

sentences.original: kitêyihtên, pêyak kêkway pîkiskwêwin nêsitohtamani nêhiyawêwin.
sentences.english: You think, 'I understand the name of one thing,' when really you understand only one word.”

sentences.original: êh-wîhtamâht ana osîkinikêw kêkway ohci kâ-minahiwêt awa, mistahi pâhpiw min êyakô.
sentences.text: ê-wîhtamâht ana osîkinikêw kêkway ohci kâ-minahiwêt awa mistahi pâhpiw mîna êwako
sentences.english: When the bartender was told why this man was standing treat, then he too had a hearty laugh
Then they went out of the place.
